text: The Song of the Vineyard
Let me sing for my beloved
a song of my love concerning his vineyard:

⸤My beloved had a vineyard⸥\f + \fr 5:1 \ft Literally “A vineyard was for my beloved” \f* on ⸤a fertile hill⸥.\f + \fr 5:1 \ft Literally “a horn of a son of olive oil.” The Hebrew for horn, \fqa qeren \ft , sounds like the Hebrew for vineyard, \fqa kerem \ft  \f*
And he dug it and cleared it of stones,
and he planted it \add with\add* choice vines,\f + \fr 5:2 \ft Hebrew “vine” \f*
and he built a watchtower in the middle of it,
and he even hewed out a wine vat in it,
and he waited for \add it\add* to yield grapes—
but it yielded wild grapes.
And now, inhabitants of Jerusalem
and men\f + \fr 5:3 \ft Hebrew “man” \f* of Judah, judge between me and my vineyard.
What more \add was there\add* to do for my vineyard that I have not done in it?
Why did I hope for \add it\add* to yield grapes, and it yielded wild grapes?
And now let me tell you what I myself am about to do to my vineyard.
\add I will\add* remove its hedge, and it shall become a devastation.
\add I will\add* break down its wall, and it shall become a trampling.
And I will make it a wasteland;
it shall not be pruned and hoed,
and it shall be overgrown \add with\add* briers\f + \fr 5:6 \ft Hebrew “brier” \f* and thornbushes.\f + \fr 5:6 \ft Hebrew “thornbush” \f*
And concerning the clouds, I will command ⸤them not to send⸥\f + \fr 5:6 \ft Literally “from sending” \f* rain down upon it.
For the vineyard of Yahweh of hosts \add is\add* the house of Israel,
and the man\f + \fr 5:7 \ft Or “people” \f* of Judah \add is\add* the plantation of his delight.
\add And\add* he waited for justice,\f + \fr 5:7 \ft The Hebrew word, \fqa mishpat, \ft sounds like \fqa mishpakh \ft in the next line \f*
but look! Bloodshed!\f + \fr 5:7 \ft The Hebrew word, \fqa mishpakh \ft , sounds like \fqa mishpat \ft in the previous line \f*
For righteousness,\f + \fr 5:7 \ft The Hebrew word, \fqa tsedaqah, \ft sounds like \fqa tsa`aqah \ft in the next line \f*
but look! A cry of distress!\f + \fr 5:7 \ft The Hebrew word, \fqa tsa`aqah, \ft sounds like \fqa tsedaqah \ft in the previous line \f*
Woes on the Wicked
Ah! Those who ⸤join⸥\f + \fr 5:8 \ft Literally “touch” \f* house with house,
they join field together with field
until ⸤there is no place⸥\f + \fr 5:8 \ft Literally “an end of place” \f*
and you are caused to dwell alone in the midst of the land.
Yahweh of hosts \add said\add* in my ears:
⸤Surely⸥\f + \fr 5:9 \ft Literally “If not” \f* many houses shall become a desolation,
large and beautiful \add ones\add* without inhabitant.
For ten acres of vineyard shall yield one bath,\f + \fr 5:10 \ft A bath is a liquid measure \f*
and \add the\add* seed of a homer will yield an ephah.\f + \fr 5:10 \ft An ephah is a dry measure equal to one-tenth of a homer \f*
Ah! Those who rise early in the morning,
they pursue strong drink.
Those who linger in the evening,
wine inflames them.
And \add there\add* will be lyre and harp,
tambourine and flute,
and wine \add at\add* their feasts,
but they do not look at the deeds\f + \fr 5:12 \ft Hebrew “deed” \f* of Yahweh,
and they do not see the work of his hands.
Therefore my people will go into exile without knowledge,
\add and\add* their\f + \fr 5:13 \ft Hebrew “its” \f* nobles\f + \fr 5:13 \ft Hebrew “noble” \f* \add will be\add* men of hunger,
and their\f + \fr 5:13 \ft Hebrew “its” \f* multitude \add is\add* parched \add with\add* thirst.
Therefore Sheol has enlarged its throat,
and it has opened wide its mouth without limit,
and her\f + \fr 5:14 \ft That is, Jerusalem’s \f* nobles\f + \fr 5:14 \ft Hebrew “noble” \f* will go down, and her multitude,
her tumult and those who revel in her.
And humankind is bowed down,
and man is brought low,
and \add the\add* eyes of \add the\add* haughty are humiliated.
But Yahweh of hosts is exalted by justice,
and the holy God shows himself holy by righteousness.
And then \add the\add* lambs will graze as \add in\add* their pasture,

and ⸤fatlings, kids\f + \fr 5:17 \ft Following the Septuagint, which reads the Hebrew \fqa grym \ft (resident aliens) as \fqa gdym \ft (young goats/sheep) \f* will eat among the sites of ruins.⸥\f + \fr 5:17 \ft Literally “and ruins, fatlings, resident aliens, will eat” \f*
Ah! Those who drag iniquity along with the cords of falsehood
and sin as with rope of the cart,
those who say,
“Let him make haste;
let him hurry his work
so that we may see it
and let it draw near
and let the plan of the holy one of Israel come
so that we may know \add it\add*!”
Ah! Those who call evil good and good evil,
those who put darkness for light and light for darkness,
those who put bitter for sweet and sweet for bitter!
Ah! \add Those who are\add* wise in their own eyes
and have understanding ⸤in their view⸥!\f + \fr 5:21 \ft Literally “before their faces” \f*
Ah! Heroes at drinking wine,
and men of capability at mixing strong drink!
Those who acquit the guilty because of a bribe
and remove \add the\add* justice of \add the\add* innocent from him.
Therefore as the tongue of fire devours the stubble,
and dry grass sinks down \add in the\add* flame,
so their root will become like \add the\add* stench,
and their blossom will go up like \add the\add* dust.
For they have rejected the instruction of Yahweh of hosts,
and they have treated the word of the holy one of Israel with contempt.
Therefore ⸤Yahweh’s wrath was kindled⸥\f + \fr 5:25 \ft Literally “the anger of Yahweh became hot” \f* against his people,
and he stretched out his hand against them\f + \fr 5:25 \ft Hebrew “it” \f* and struck them,\f + \fr 5:25 \ft Hebrew “it” \f*
and the mountains quaked,
and their corpses\f + \fr 5:25 \ft Hebrew “corpse” \f* were like refuse in \add the\add* middle of \add the\add* streets.
Yahweh’s Outstretched Hand
In all of this his anger has not turned back,
and still his hand is stretched out.
And he will raise a signal for a nation\f + \fr 5:26 \ft The Hebrew is plural, but the following verses refer to the nation as singular \f* from afar,
and he will whistle for it from the end of the earth.
And look! It comes quickly, swiftly!
None \add is\add* weary,
and none among him stumbles;
none slumbers and none sleeps.
And no loincloth on his waist is opened,
and no thong of his sandals is drawn away.
Whose arrows are sharp,
and all of his bows are bent.
The hoofs of his horses are reckoned like flint,
and his wheels like the storm wind.
His roaring \add is\add* like the lion,
and he roars like young lions.
And he growls and seizes his prey,
and he carries \add it\add* off,
and not one can rescue \add it\add*.
And he will roar over him on that day
like \add the\add* roaring of \add the\add* sea,
and \add if\add* one looks to the land, look! Darkness! Distress!
And \add the\add* light grows dark with its\f + \fr 5:30 \ft Presumably the land’s \f* clouds.
